articles.headline: NBC News Is Said to Woo Former Chief to Return
articles.snippet: The company is in advanced discussions with its former news chief, Andrew Lack, about returning to the network, multiple NBC executives said on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: The company is in advanced discussions with its former news chief, Andrew Lack, about returning to the network, multiple NBC executives said on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking to contain the damage from the Brian Williams crisis and put an end to a series of management missteps that has left NBC News in turmoil, NBCUniversal is preparing to shake up the executive ranks of its news division.

articles.headline: White House Plans No Rescue if Court Guts Health Care Law
articles.snippet: Legal experts say the White House is savvy to make sure the Supreme Court knows there would be no safety net for up to 7.5 million who could lose insurance subsidies.
articles.abstract: Legal experts say the White House is savvy to make sure the Supreme Court knows there would be no safety net for up to 7.5 million who could lose insurance subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court prepares to hear arguments on Wednesday on whether to invalidate a crucial part of the president’s health care law, Obama administration officials say they are doing nothing to prepare for what could be a catastrophic defeat.

articles.headline: School Agenda Bedevils Chicago Mayor in Race
articles.snippet: As Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago faces an unexpected runoff election, it is his education agenda that threatens his political future.
articles.abstract: As Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago faces an unexpected runoff election, it is his education agenda that threatens his political future.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The sky-blue paint has begun to peel on the three-story building that was once Anthony Overton Elementary. Window air-conditioners are speckled with rust. Doors where children used to rush in and out are sealed with plywood.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Ferguson Police Routinely Violate Rights of Blacks, Justice Dept. Finds
articles.snippet: A department report, which says officials made racist jokes about blacks on their city email accounts, concluded that officers made unjustified traffic stops for years.
articles.abstract: A department report, which says officials made racist jokes about blacks on their city email accounts, concluded that officers made unjustified traffic stops for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ferguson, Mo., is a third white, but the crime statistics compiled in the city over the past two years seemed to suggest that only black people were breaking the law. They accounted for 85 percent of traffic stops, 90 percent of tickets and 93 percent of arrests. In cases like jaywalking, which often hinge on police discretion, blacks accounted for 95 percent of all arrests.

articles.headline: Americans Aren’t Saving Enough for Retirement, but One Change Could Help
articles.snippet: The typical remedy is that people should put more money aside in investments. This glosses over a critical driver of unpreparedness: Wall Street is bleeding savers dry.
articles.abstract: The typical remedy is that people should put more money aside in investments. This glosses over a critical driver of unpreparedness: Wall Street is bleeding savers dry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here is something every non-rich American family should know: The odds are that you will run out of money in retirement.

articles.headline: Equity Firms Are Lending to Landlords, Signaling a Shift
articles.snippet: Three large private equity firms are lending to small and midsize investors who are buying single-family homes.
articles.abstract: Three large private equity firms are lending to small and midsize investors who are buying single-family homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the financial crisis, large private equity firms spent tens of billions of dollars buying foreclosed homes across the United States to operate them as rental properties.

articles.headline: Japan’s Growth in Solar Power Falters as Utilities Balk
articles.snippet: Solar power generators have proliferated in Japan as part of an effort to promote green energy, but utilities say they can’t cope with the expansion.
articles.abstract: Solar power generators have proliferated in Japan as part of an effort to promote green energy, but utilities say they can’t cope with the expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAKURAZAKI, Japan — Rice fields, golf courses and even a disused airport runway. All over the southern Japanese region of Kyushu, unexpected places gleam with electricity-producing solar panels.

articles.headline: Nextdoor Social Network Digs Deep Into Neighborhoods
articles.snippet: The start-up and its investors see opportunities in the company’s more than 53,000 microcommunities.
articles.abstract: The start-up and its investors see opportunities in the company’s more than 53,000 microcommunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Internet companies have been trying desperately for years to court people like Isaac Gonzalez to use their services.

articles.headline: Using Private Email, Hillary Clinton Thwarted Record Requests
articles.snippet: For nearly two years after Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped down from her secretary of state post, the State Department was unable to search her emails in response to records requests.
articles.abstract: For nearly two years after Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped down from her secretary of state post, the State Department was unable to search her emails in response to records requests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, congressional investigators asked the State Department for a wide range of documents related to the attack on the United States diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya. The department eventually responded, furnishing House committees with thousands of documents.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: In Chase of Apple, Smartphone Makers Shift Strategies
articles.snippet: With its vast share of the industry’s profits, Apple was the target at the Mobile World Congress, where Samsung and Microsoft are trying to position their products as business tools.
articles.abstract: With its vast share of the industry’s profits, Apple was the target at the Mobile World Congress, where Samsung and Microsoft are trying to position their products as business tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Big phones, small phones, cheap phones, expensive phones, curved phones — and all of them hoping to take a chunk out of the iPhone.

articles.headline: At Least One Justice Is in Play as Supreme Court Hears Affordable Care Act Case
articles.snippet: Oral arguments in the Supreme Court case on the Affordable Care Act included surprising comments from Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.
articles.abstract: Oral arguments in the Supreme Court case on the Affordable Care Act included surprising comments from Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday took up the Affordable Care Act in one of the most anticipated arguments of the term, and it seemed closely divided over the fate of President Obama’s signature legislative achievement.

articles.headline: McDonald’s Moving to Limit Antibiotic Use in Chickens
articles.snippet: The chain said that within two years its domestic restaurants would no longer use birds treated with antibiotics “important to human medicine.”
articles.abstract: The chain said that within two years its domestic restaurants would no longer use birds treated with antibiotics “important to human medicine.”
articles.lead_paragraph: McDonald’s said on Wednesday that it would begin using chickens that are not raised with antibiotics used to treat humans, a move likely to put pressure on competitors of the fast-food chain, which now sells more chicken than beef.
